title: Late Ottoman Palestinians: Social and Cultural Dynamics in an Eastern Mediterranean Society during the Age of Empire, 1880-1920
descriptions: This grant proposal seeks funding to conduct research on social strategies employed by late Ottoman Palestinians between 1880 and 1920. The project will focus on individual and collective practices for coping with challenges, using census data as a primary source. By examining how individuals across ethnic, religious, and class divides navigated social and economic stress, the study aims to shed light on the emergence and re-emergence of social formations in the region. The research will contribute to a broader understanding of social and cultural dynamics in late Ottoman Palestine within the context of European imperialism, Ottoman state building, and globalisation. Additionally, the project will develop a theoretical framework and methodological standards for similar research endeavors, with the ultimate goal of creating a Historical Geographic Information System (HGIS) for the entire Ottoman Empire. The findings may also provide new insights into the study of colonialism, particularly under the British Mandate. By establishing comparative yardsticks and innovative research methodologies, this project will advance the field of global social and cultural history, offering a nuanced perspective on the complex social landscape of the Eastern Mediterranean during this transformative period.

**Description:**

In the Eastern Mediterranean, the four decades between 1880 and 1920 were a time of imperialism, globalisation and Ottoman state building, but also of profound social differentiation, fuelled by an unprecedented degree of human mobility and migration. Therefore, in this period we find the roots of many social formations that have remained relevant until the present. My focus is on the individual and collective practices for coping with various challenges and on census-taking as a social process. It will open up new perspectives on social and cultural dynamics in late Ottoman Palestine, in a historical context defined by European imperialism, Ottoman state building and globalisation.
